docs.lead_paragraph: IT isn't easy to become a Jew in Westchester. According to Jewish tradition, converts must be immersed in the mikvah, a ritual bath built according to strict Talmudic standards.

headline.main: A New Jewish Home For an Ancient Practice

docs.abstract: Temple Israel, Conservative Jewish congregation in White Plains, plans to build mikvah, ritual bath that could be used by converts, which should be completed in fall; photo (M)
docs.snippet: IT isn't easy to become a Jew in Westchester.     According to Jewish tradition, converts must be immersed in the mikvah, a ritual bath built according to strict Talmudic standards.

docs.lead_paragraph: France's highest administrative court today reversed a decision that had allowed nurses in high school health centers to hand out a ''morning-after pill'' to prevent pregnancies. The Council of State overruled a decision made by an education minister last year, saying that the official had misunderstood a 1967 law, which says that hormonal contraceptives may be distributed only under prescription by pharmacies.

headline.main: No More 'Morning-After Pills' At School, French Court Says

docs.abstract: France's highest administrative court reverses a decision that had allowed nurses in high school health centers to hand out 'morning-after pill' to prevent pregnancies; Council of State overrules decision made by education minister last year, saying that official had misunderstood 1967 law, which says that hormonal contraceptives may be distributed only under prescriptions by pharmacies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an off-the-rack world, Hong Kong remains stubbornly made-to-measure. Wander into any alleyway off the main shopping boulevard, Queen's Road, and you can order tailored suits, personalized Chinese scrolls, custom-designed furniture or handmade shoes. Tucked in one of these narrow streets -- behind locked doors on the eighth floor of a nondescript office building -- is Anthony S. Y. Wong's fertility clinic. For $2,450, Mr. Wong offers the ultimate in customized service: he helps prospective parents choose the sex of their children.

headline.main: Hong Kong Journal; Clinic Caters to Couples Seeking 'Precious Gem'

docs.abstract: Comment on social-phenomenon that is little-discussed but widely prevalent in Hong Kong: determination to control virtually every facet of child-birth; from selecting the sex to scheduling the delivery, people in Hong Kong go to extraordinary lengths; there are clinics to help prospective parents choose sex of their children; 90 percent of customers choose boys, which draws fierce criticism from doctors and politicians, who contend practice is reckless form of genetic engineering; photos (L)/
